body: I don’t see this deal benefiting Nvidia long term; it’s a setup so NIO can steal their IP.

author: westerhong
body:
AAPL

I bought a bunch of AAPL in 2010 when Steve Jobs passed. It’s grown to be over 50% of my portfolio even as I keep buying other stocks. It just keeps going up. Every time I rebalance or try to diversify I regret it. 

Their recent innovation with their silicon is off the charts and should make holders of intel, AMD, and NVDA very worried. The growth in their services revenue is such an impressive pivot. Amazing brand value, huge margins and stockpiles of cash. And they’ve proven that they have a company DNA that extends beyond any one figure or product.

There will always be an apple hating crowd, and the company is a bit too full of itself. But it’s a company I feel good investing in unlike Facebook.

author: Sensei071
body: Still no new factory / vertical integration nor updates on expansion to Europe. Solid state battery isn’t product ready until the end of 2022 at the earliest. And they won’t have control over the production pipeline since they are adopting someone else’s solid state battery (either CATL or Prologium). New self driving development via partnership with Nvidia is great but not groundbreaking. A lot of auto manufacturers are already using Nvidia’s platform to develop self driving like Xpeng and Li. ET7 is promising but won’t be delivered until Q1, 2022 at the earliest. It’s also an ultra premium sedan that competes w/ model S which really hasn’t been the moneymaker of all EV models.  Perhaps they will release a more affordable sedan next. I think Nio will be successful as long as they could execute the long term initiatives. But let’s not kid ourselves that there were no flaws in the Nio Day’s presentation. I own a good amount of Nio shares myself but also gotta be realistic as an investor here.

author: stevenconrad
body: A lot, actually. WSB is usually right, but timing can be way off. I've seen TSLA, GME, PLTR, BB, BBBY, MT, NVDA, AMD, MSFT, F, GE, etc. All with gains and losses,  but mostly through options. Miss time it, and you're fkd. Buy shares an you'll usually win, but with options you'll fly or fall.

author: lowrankcluster
body: Nvidia makes the best chips for neural network computation. Good to see that they are not stopping to innovate in both hardware and software support despite no competition.

author: Leon91
body: And precisely because they can't compete NOW, intel is undervalued. But they're sitting on a mad stack of cash, have a ton of engineers, are looking to outsource to TSMC as well and they will always get back. Maybe you haven't noticed, but Intel/AMD and before ATi/NVidia is very cyclical.

author: LiveLaughLibor
body: I was holding NVDA from 2017 onwards. The sell off in late 2018 and early 2019 was extremely painful and mentally scaring/conditioning when it comes to my investing philosophy. Watching your shares tank 40% in value is an experience I honestly hope every investor goes through once and only one time. After you go through it you stop caring so much about the intraday swings. This new cohort of investors who have made their money in 2020 need to experience a bear market to teach them some lessons on investing.

body:
Decided yesterday, after some considerable DD & 9 drinks, to do the same on Tuesday.


Selling all my Ark F&G, NVDA, MSFT, etc.

It’s all going in BB.

I’m done being in stocks that are trading at 40+ times earnings.

BB is at 4.5 x earnings. It has the power of the meme. It has a real competitive advantage & a value prop.

It’s already made me + 50% in my first 750 shares.

Long live Cathy, long live Chen.

Rebalancing to 100% BB & deleting my TD Ameritrade app.

See ya in a few years!🚀🚀🚀🚀

author: galactojack
body:
I go for the tech, renewable, cybersecurity, cloud, and a bit of pot stocks- this decade should be great for those

For less risk, I go with NEE, BEP, Nvidia, and Disney. Next Era Energy and Brookfield Renewable - they're already the kings of the U.S. renewable utility market, and pay dividends. Dividends + growth = booya. Nvidia for obvious reasons and their new AI tech, and Disney because they've been slowly taking over the digital entertainment market (i.e. ESPN and all the new streaming hits) and once their parks are doing well again it'll probably accelerate really quickly.

Cybersecurity is only just getting going too with nearly infinite room for growth, Zscaler and Crowdstrike are doing extraordinarily well.

For more risk, my renewable riskies (but are still leaders in their industry) are BLDP, SEDG, LAZR, and QS. BLDP and SEDG are reliable, the others fairly speculative but with strong futures if all goes well. I'm looking forward to Lion going public soon, as Amazon backs them. I have some in Fisker as well, I think they've got potential and they seem to have their ducks in a row this time around with a manufacturing partnership already lined up.

And then some of the pot stocks, Aphria has good numbers and IIPR deals in buying properties for new dispensaries instead of dealing with the trickiness of making pot profitable. Should be a really great stock to have as legalization continues to expand

And of course, my SPCE Virgin Galactic has had consistent growth with some exciting swells, but will only moon once they actually start giving space flight tours to the 600+ wealthy elite who've already reserved their tickets. But as it dips after every surge, it's a great time to get in.

&#x200B;

Clearly I'm very diversified but with a decent amount of risk

author: Turtlesaur
body:
This will be the death of the sub, brigading every idea that isn't inline with there own and suppressing new ideas.   
  
The way this sub is today, this current GME craze would have never seen the light of day, snuffed out under AMD, NVDA, TSLA, PLTR spam.   
  
I'm 4 years+ on this sub and own GME and am holding it. I also own SLV because I have enough money to diversify. Going all in on 1 basket is something a single, middle to lower age 20s would do. Some of us have families. If I went all in on GME and something happened, I would likely get a divorce, lose my kids, be outcast by my family and have ruined my children's lovely hoods.  
  
  
Tl;dr this is a sub for ideas, and not everyone is you, in your immediate position.   
  
(50 GME at $212)

author: Coat_Dry
body:
“Nobody drives anymore, there’s too much traffic”

AMD shipped damn near 10Million PS5/Xbox chips, and they shipped as much GPU volume as NVidia while also eating into Intel’s market share.

I heard they were TSMC’s biggest customer by volume(TSM is running at 120% capacity FYI). The world wasn’t prepared for COVID so supply lines are tight, but that means the 🚀🚀🚀isn’t going to be as big as it could be, not that it won’t happen at all.

author: GradExMachina
body:
Doubt.

1. As long as x86 is the main platform for pcs, AMD needs Intel and Intel needs AMD because these two and only these two hold x86-84 and x86 licenses. (There's a chinese company that has x86-64 but it's irrelevant). Without one another, either will be treated as monopoly. The only scenario where this doesn't hold is when arm gets a proper footprint, but so far only NVDA and Amazon can be a challenge for x86 unless AAPL starts selling CPUs.
2. The US govt will never let Intel sink, simply because they will keep contracts. They can not risk internal information leaking to other countries, especially regarding ring -1 (and even lower). That would open them to vulnerabilities.  
3. Intel really loves backwards compatibility and so do governments.

author: mgm50
body:
This is going to be biased because I work tech-side for the semiconductor design industry, so keep that in mind, but the sector is currently facing immense demand and is bound to grow even more in the next years.

Part of the reason is that every single sector you mentioned is consolidating a reliance on customized chip building, to the point that even IBM, NVidia, Sony, etc. (all of the big players and most medium ones) now have contracts with companies whose sole purpose is to put a dozen of top researchers inside a room and come up with new designs and devices they can sell to the big players to fabricate. 

The second part of it is that R&D on fundamental electronics is speeding up as Moore's law comes to saturation, rather than slowing down. Spintronics, Photonics, Phononics are all words you'll soon be reading on the mainstream news as people develop neuromorphic computers to act as machine learning ASICs (application-specific integrated circuits), circuits that integrate with living tissue, electronic clothing, and so on. The pressure in our little corner of the industry is building up quite fast and we're having to train Phds on the fly to keep up with demand growth.

author: llllllllllllllll12
body:
5 years ago I had about $20k saved and decided it was time to start investing. I moved it into my E*Trade account and bought FANNG It worked well... but one stock in particular crushed it... $NVDA [in @$63] From that point forward I was chasing the fast money.

I then decided to get approved for options, and  like most most of you, I wasn’t a retard (yet). I played it safe and bought LEAPs on $SQ [in @ $24] expiring 2 years out. Satisfied with this decision and it’s initial momentum I started studying up on options... when I came across /WallStreetBets.

The hype stock at the time was AMD... several others came and went. I saw so many people YOLOing on weeklies I thought it was hilarious and said I’d never do that.

I did however become riskier with my trades... I got approved for margin and maxed out on FANG, bought more LEAPs and decided to put 10% of my portfolio on an $ADBE earnings with OTM calls... they printed... +700% or $15k in like 48 hours. It was my very first weekly... I was officially a retard.

Now at this time, the Trump rally was like 18 months strong and every small dip recovered within a week... so I was sure at the next dip, 
I’d capitalize. At the time $AMZN was just on fire so at that next dip I bought $2000 OTM Calls expiring one month out... the EV on this was EXPENSIVE. So I was really pushing the limit.

Then came the dip. (Summer 2018) Only this time, it didn’t recover, the market just sucked ass for like a week... I got margin called and had to sell all my stocks at a loss, but held on to all my options. The $AMZN call evaporated instantly. And by then I had lost like 2 years of gains $130k in about three days.

At that point I was terrified that the whole market was going to collapse... that there was something I was not privy to. Like the housing bubble of 2008... so I sold everything I had left, and stopped investing for a year.

The recovery came and went, the summer of 2018 just looked like a speed bump in hindsight. So I told myself I’d wait for the next dip... I was patient. 

Waited over a year and boy did that dip come. COVID-19... up 320% since COVID. Never had the courage to tell anyone about my shitty summer of 2018 until now... It’s a lesson I had to learn otherwise I’d still be trading like a lunatic until I hit a land mine. So those of you posting losses feeling like it’s the end of the world... 🍻cheers to getting your cherry 🍒 popped and welcome to /WallStreetBets


** green line shows E*TRADE balance before it was merged into Robinhood.

**TLDR - crazy gains 2 years ago trading like junior varsity retard, lost 80% in three days. Now making it back trading like a Varsity retard

author: the_dean_list
body:
So for the past year or so I’ve become more knowledgeable and invested in the stock market. Through reading and watching YouTube videos online, I’ve taught myself technical analysis and the ability to distinguish well-run companies from bad ones. One company in particular that I’ve been following has been AMD.

AMD is a company that is close to my heart and many of you as well because we use their products. Whether you’re PC Master Race or a console player, AMD has had a significant impact on your gaming life. With the release of their new Ryzen Zen 3 CPUs and 6 series graphics cards, they have completely turned the Computer & Graphics industry on its head and are siphoning a growing percentage of market share from industry leaders such as Intel and Nvidia.

This became very evident when they announced their Q4 earnings report this past Tuesday. To put it simply, they CRUSHED IT. AMD’s revenue was up 45% in 2020, led by the growth of the companies server CPU and game console CPU segments which increased by 176% year over year.

On the earnings call, AMD’s CEO, Lisa Su, gave great guidance and announced AMD expects 37% revenue growth in 2021 despite supply issue concerns due to the pandemic.

So why am I writing all of this? Since AMD announced its earnings on Tuesday, the stock has plummeted almost 10 percent due to market manipulation. It’s no secret that large hedge funds are trying to cover the losses they’ve endured in stocks like $GME and $AMC by shorting well-performing stocks that retail investors are heavily invested in. And yesterday Robinhood facilitated this transfer of wealth by preventing retail investors from buying more than one share of $AMD at a time.

Herein lies the problem. We are told in this country to pick ourselves up by our own bootstraps. To put in the effort and the work and you’ll be rewarded. But the events of the past week have made it evidently clear that the “American Dream” only applies to a select segment of the population. Because whenever the working class beats the rich at their own rules, they immediately change the rules to punish us. It’s honestly sickening.

So what can we do to combat this? Essentially, what the large hedge funds are doing right now is a high stakes game of rob Peter to pay Paul. They have lost billions in $GME and $AMC so now they are attacking (shorting) larger market cap stocks to make up the difference. WE CANNOT ALLOW THEM TO DO THIS. If we do not fight back, we will allow them to continue the status quo of changing the rules for their benefit.

I am not a financial advisor, but we need to do what we can to protect companies such as $AMD and any of the other companies Robinhood has targeted over the past couple of days. If we’re able to beat these hedge funds at their own games, maybe our government can finally intervene, which could lead to policy reform/regulation that supports the retail investor. Maybe I’m being overly optimistic, but who knows. I think we really have a revolution on our hands here if this becomes a full fledged grassroots movement.

author: bestsparkyalive
body:
You would not have held that to completion of your million dollar profit targets.   You would not.  If you constantly spend emotional capital reminiscent on what could have been, I don't think you would have had the mental fortitude to hold that long at the time. 

We all suffer from this.  It's not only you it's human.  Growth from this place of mental suffering will come.  Just use this energy for something good.  Do some research.   Find the next big thing.  How is the current economic landscape about to shift?

How is the new administration and its policies going to affect things going forward?

So many questions... So many profitable answers to be had.  You got this.  Move on.  Tesla, NIO, PLUG, CVRS, STXS, AMD, NVDA, IVN, CRSP, SPWR, ENPH, and so much more comprise a list of stocks I either lost money on or sold for small profits like you did.  These stocks would have netted me incredible profits.

But thats ok.  We should be grateful we have the intelligence and the ability to find plays that will pay out down the road.  That we live lifestyles that let us spend money and multiply it.  There's so many people in the world who would kill for a chance to just get to study the market in your spare time as a hobby... 

Let's be grateful.  Don't be bitter.  Be grateful.  Sorry for the spew of words, I can just relate.
